title: Six revellers are rushed to hospital from Listen Out music festival in Sydney
text:
Six young revellers were rushed to hospital with drug overdoses from the Listen Out music festival in Sydney this weekend.

The victims were among nine people, all aged in their 20s, hospitalised during the 10-hour event at Centennial Parklands on Saturday.

More than 40,000 music fans braved a gauntlet of police and sniffer dogs to get inside the festival gates to see artists like Flume and Diplo.

Dozens of officers patrolled the event and stood at the entrance as part of the NSW Government's ongoing crackdown on music festivals.

Numerous attendees were denied entry for trying to smuggle drugs or alcohol inside and others kicked out or arrested during the event.

The six overdoses was the lowest since 2016 when just three were rushed to hospital. There were 10 last year and seven in 2017.

Listen Out followed regulations brought in by the government despite them being repealed by parliament last month.

The law forced an arbitrary list of 11 'high risk' venues to abide by a list of stricter conditions and obtain a special liquor licence.

Premier Gladys Berejiklian commended the organisers for working with authorities to 'act as though the regulations are still in place'.

Six young revellers were rushed to hospital with drug overdoses from the Listen Out music festival in Sydney this weekend

Adelle Robinson, director of Listen Out organiser Fuzzy Operations, told the committee overseeing the regulations she was 'not exactly sure why' the event were slapped with the 'high risk' status.

She said 'there was a definite reputational damage' from being among the 11 events and 'everyone has been operating in an atmosphere of fear'.

Fuzzy was forced to pay $171,927 under the 'user pays' system of charging organisers for mandatory police presence based on attendee numbers.

Ms Berejiklian has also rejected pill testing, previously stating that there's 'not enough evidence' that it works.

'They haven't shown there's any evidence yet,' the Premier explained.

'My position on pill testing remains firm. I don't think it works, I don't think the evidence is there and I don't support it.'

Pill testing would allow revellers to know how strong a pill was before it was taken and cautioned about the risk.

Critics said such testing gave tacit approval to illegal activity and a misreading of tablet strength could lead people into a false sense of security.

Listen Out is an over 18s Australian dance and music event, featuring multiple hip hop and electronic artists across four inner city venues across the country.

Some patrons arrived wearing very risqué outfits ready to have a fun-filled day listening to the long list of artists who were due to play.

Australian record producer, Flume, made a special appearance and performed for the first time in the country since the Falls Festival last year.

There was a marked police presence for the start of the festival season after five young revellers died at events last spring and summer due to suspected drug overdoses.
description: The victims aged in their 20s were among 40,000 people who flocked to the dance music festival in Sydney on Saturday with numerous patrons turned away at the door or arrested.
authors: Nic White For Daily Mail Australia
